headline.main: On Show, A New Dutch Master

lead_paragraph: HELLA JONGERIUS likes working the barricades of experimental design. While others swanned around in Missoni gowns and iridescent silks at a gala opening at the Museum of Modern Art two weeks ago, she stood in a pinstripe suit handing out her manifestoes. The inventions she had on display at the show of designs for working life were typical of her rough-textured, conceptually clever style: a fur-covered floor cushion implanted with a laptop, a computer keyboard with a built-in snack bowl and a workaholics' bed with his and her computers sunk into the mattress. (Groping for the mouse? It's the throw pillow.)
abstract: Julie V Iovine on work of Dutch designer Hella Jongerius, which is on exhibit at Museum of Modern Art; photos (M)
